author: Keith Groller
title: Becahi's Spigner is headed to Lafayette
text:
Not all was lost for Lafayette last weekend.
The Leopards may have lost a game to Harvard, but they gained one of the area's best athletes and quarterbacks when Bethlehem Catholic senior Julian Spigner took to Twitter on Sunday to announce he's headed to College Hill.
The 6-foot-3, 195-pound Spigner has completed 77 of 125 passes this season for 1,159 yards and eight touchdowns. He also has run for 441 yards on 61 carries and seven more scores.
In his career, he has thrown for nearly 4,900 yards and 54 touchdowns.
Spigner, a three-year starter who has led the Golden Hawks to back-to-back District 11 3A titles, has drawn praise from head coach Joe Henrich for his versatility and for being a team leader.
He is the second area quarterback to commit to Lafayette, joining Notre Dame's Tre Jordan, who began his career at Pius X. The Crusaders and Golden Hawks are a combined 13-1.

Holy Cross gave it a great try but came up short at Fordham on Saturday as the Rams' Chase Edmonds scored on a 7-yard run in overtime to give his team a 47-41 win.
Edmonds was his usual dominant self with 162 yards and four touchdowns, but the amazing offensive performer in the Bronx was Holy Cross quarterback Peter Pujals, who completed 35 of 70 passes for 508 yards and four touchdowns.
He was an obvious choice as Patriot League offensive player of the week.
Pujals' passing yards and total offense (526) were both school records. The 508 passing yards was also the top passing total in FCS football this season. Both were also fourth best in Patriot League history.
Three Crusaders receivers went over the 100-yard mark in the game â€” Brendan Flaherty (143 yards), Kalif Raymond (140), Jake Wieczorek (110).
It's not a surprise that Holy Cross is No. 1 in the league in passing.
Did you know?
The James Madison campus in Harrisonburg, Va., where Lehigh was thumped 55-17 on Sept. 12, will welcome ESPN's GameDay crew on Saturday prior to the Dukes' game against No. 13 Richmond.
JMU is 7-0 and ranked No. 3 by one national FCS poll and No. 4 by the other and features one of the best players in FCS football in Georgia Tech transfer Vad Lee. Lee has passed for 1,896 yards and 19 touchdowns and has run for 690 yards and five TDs.
Royal call
Matt Martucci, who was the class salutatorian when he graduated from Pius X in 2002, will be the play-by-play announcer for the Lehigh-Fordham game Saturday. The game can be seen on the Patriot League Network.
Martucci's brother, Nick, was a standout player at Lehigh from 1995-98, starting in all 46 games of his career. He helped the Mountain Hawks win two Patriot League championships and was also a co-captain his senior year (1998) when Lehigh went 12-1 and defeated Richmond in the first round of the FCS playoffs.
The older Martucci was also a standout player at Pius X.
The younger Martucci is a Syracuse grad and has worked Saint Joseph's men's and women's basketball games in recent years as well as the Philadelphia Soul.
More royalty
Speaking of Pius X products, Phil Stambaugh, who still holds Lehigh's record for passing yards in a career with 10,575 and TD passes (78), became a father for the first time Wednesday when his wife, Courtney, gave birth to a daughter. Brooklyn Isabella Stambaugh checked in at 6 pounds, 13 ounces at 6:15 Wednesday morning.
Stambaugh is now the assistant head coach and offensive coordinator at Notre Dame-Green Pond.
